29.text:
Welcome to Fieldsports Britain, coming to
you this week from Scotland. This is the estuary

35.text: of the river Nith in Dumfrieshire.

38.text:
We are out with Solway stalker Colin Lockerbie
just here. We are finding out why everybody

45.text:
comes to Fife. It is the pigeons and roebuck
of course. Fox shooting blunders. How can

53.text:
First it is our popular new series Test Splat
Special.

61.text:
For this week's Test Splat Special we are
mainly shooting a piece of frost-bitten pork.

69.text:
We don't like wasting food, but this test
should give us an idea about the performance

75.text:
of a .243 100-grain soft point bullet from
120ish yards on a decent chunk of meat.

81.text:
So what are the possibilities for porcine
aviation today? How far will a pig fly? Will

94.text:
The first shot is taken using 240 frames per
second and if you look closely you can see

99.text: the bullet coming in from the right of frame.

102.text:
It splits the pork, but leaves it in situ,
so a chance of another go. Again the bullet

107.text:
is visible on the image recorded at 480 frames
per second.

112.text:
Finally, a third shot and we are aiming for
the bone to provide some resistance. This

121.text:
image is taken at 1,000 frames per second
- and the pig has wings.

127.text:
So let's get the tape out aaaaaaand we are
going to have to get a bigger tape measure

133.text:
- the pork has been sent well over 15 metres
away from the target position - so anyone

138.text:
who chose (c) far and wide earns the approbation
of the masses.

142.text:
Please don't have nightmares - nothing proved
nothing gained - just for fun - next week

147.text: a kettle and firebird with an air rifle.

150.text:
We have got other test splats like this egg
that is just appearing in the sky beside me.

156.text: Click on it and you can see more of them.

158.text:
Now, on to the serious stuff. We are out with
Zeiss professional stalker Colin Lockerbie

165.text:
It is early in the morning in the village
of New Abbey, just south of Dumfries. Solway

170.text:
stalker Colin Lockerbie has a client, Gary,
who wants a roebuck.

175.text:
Roebucks today Charlie. Have a look over the
wee cliff there. It has been cut recently

180.text:
and is going to be replanted later this year,
so see how we can do there. I have spotted

183.text:
a couple of roebucks there recently so hopefully
they will be about.

190.text:
Colin offers deer and wild boar stalking across
20,000 acres of southern Scotland. He is one

196.text:
of the most respected stalkers in Scotland
and a Zeiss Professional Hunter to boot.

201.text:
We check out clear-felled plantations and
we go for a walk along the beach. The estuary

208.text:
of the River Nith is big, flat and its creeks
provide food for deer in the early morning.

214.text:
As we walk along, we put one up. Were we making
too much noise? Was the animal lucky? It sure

220.text:
Just heard the movement in the bank there
and saw it run off about 5 or 10 seconds later,

227.text: it was a doe which ran off onto the foreshore.

232.text:
We enter a small bluebell wood and there is
a buck. But there is no way Gary is going

237.text:
to risk firing a round through this kind of
thick cover

241.text:
I tried to put the cross hair just onto its
neck, but just could not take the shot. If

247.text:
it went through that bush it would just deflect
off and more chance of doing him great damage

253.text:
As the day warms up, so do the arguments about
whether or not we were making too much noise.

259.text:
Colin's boots have been making a squelching,
squeaking sound. My cheap Dunlops have been

264.text:
badly clumpy and Gary's boots look far too
shabby to be silent.

269.text:
Well one of the issues about this morning’s
stalk is the squeak in our boots and we have

274.text:
been complaining to each other about that.
So we thought we would do a little test. I

278.text:
will take the Fieldsports Channel microphone
here and I will attach it to each of our boots

282.text:
and you can tell which one you think is the
squeakiest.

294.text:
In the end, I am disqualified for tiptoeing,
Colin bows out because his boots are wet on

300.text:
the inside, so Gary is declared Mr Cat-Like
Tread 2012. He admits that part of the reason

307.text:
his boots are so supple and silent is that
they are made of kangaroo skin.

312.text:
Now, Colin is not just a deerstalker. He has
a small, but growing population of wild or

320.text:
This is where wild boar have been rooting
about here. That was in October last year.

323.text: In October? That is almost 8 months ago.

328.text: And it is still torn up.

329.text:
Yes, difficult land for the farmer to repair.
So it will probably have to stay like that.

337.text: You do wild boar shooting here don’t you?

341.text: Yes I feed them to highseats yes.

344.text:
So you are trying to contain them in one area?
So how does that work?

347.text:
Yes, just try to keep the farmers happy really.
We draw them to an area just over here. Maybe

354.text:
have a highseat set up over there. We have
not actually shot any on this area here, so

359.text:
I would expect to see them back again probably
same time next year after they have eaten

364.text: So they eat acorns then come and root up fields.

366.text:
Come and root up the fields for a bit of meat
in their diet as well after they have eaten

374.text:
One in three of Colin's boar outings succeeded
last year. Boar shot ranged from 30kg to these

382.text:
Just put the seat up here a couple of weeks
ago. The pigs found the food pretty quickly.

392.text:
They were here feeding every night and I put
food out just 2 nights, every second night

398.text: When are you going to shoot them?

399.text:
I won’t shoot here now until October. There
is a big sow feeding here with youngsters

403.text: now, so I will leave them alone for the summer.

409.text:
There is not much about Solway fish and game
that Colin doesn't know or cannot provide.

417.text:
The Nith nearly scored Britain's biggest rod-caught
salmon when a monster weighing around 100lb

423.text:
fought and beat a bishop in the 19th century.
It was later caught in nets with the bishop's

428.text:
fly still in its mouth. Colin cannot boast
a fish that big in his lifetime but he is

434.text: a master of the old Viking practice of haafnetting.

436.text: How do you know you have got a fish?

439.text:
When the water is racing through the net here,
you hold the net with your thumb, the net

445.text:
is quite tight here and you just feel a tug
on your finger. Then you lift and the fish

451.text: will be back in the net here.

452.text: How do you get it out of that?

454.text:
Again it is very simple. You catch the net
and throw it over into the net so that it

461.text:
is double netted then hanging over here and
you carry a priest in your bag just to kill

466.text:
the fish, throw it back over and lift it out.
It is fairly easy once you have done one or

473.text: Is this what you call commercial netting?

476.text:
No, it is more or less just a hobby now. There
is not the number of fish there used to be

482.text: a few years back. So it is really just a hobby.

485.text:
You are not going to take me in there because
they are not running at the moment.

490.text:
They are not running, it is too cold in the
water, they stay there very long just now.

493.text:
There are other ways to catching fish round
here. Colin takes us to see Peter Hutchison,

498.text: who has bigger nets on the Solway

499.text:
These are salmon stake nets. They call them
fixed engine fishery nets. They are an old

506.text:
style of fishing along the Solway coast here
for salmon. They have been on the go here

512.text:
in the Solway for well over 200 years. There
are not many left now, a lot of the fisheries

517.text: have gone. We still enjoy using them here.

520.text: You catch all sorts as well as salmon?

522.text:
We get a range of fish that go from tope,
tope is typically the largest fish right down

529.text:
through to shard which are of the herring
family. They are currently taken into research

536.text:
projects, Solway wide at the moment. So we
give them to the Galloway Fishery Trust. Salmon

542.text:
and sea trout, that is the main issue for
us. We get some lovely turbot now and again

547.text:
and a few other things. The variety is always
fun.

551.text:
Now, the day is growing cool once again, and
Colin and Gary still have an appointment with

556.text:
a buck. Colin takes us to a new plantation
which has been suffering roe damage recently.

562.text:
All thoughts of the long walks and missed
opportunities from earlier in the day fly

566.text: away because there is Gary's animal.

570.text:
They want these animals culled on this particular
plantation, young plantation. There was not

575.text:
much option on shot placement, the only option
I really had there was a neck shot which is

581.text:
You have got an enormous variety of ground
here, you have got hill, you have got shoreline,

Yes, a good mixture of everything which helps
depending on the weather. If the weather is

595.text:
not suitable to be out on the hill, you can

602.text:
A plantation like the one, you can’t see

612.text:
Yes, pretty much a banker. You know there
will always be something about in a place

620.text:
Colin charges £70 per roebuck outing, plus

626.text:
off him and he runs an eight-strong syndicate

639.text:
We love our deer at Fieldsports Channel. Look,

click on it you can see more of our deer stalking

648.text:
Now it is David on the Fieldsports Channel
News Stump.

661.text:
We start with Channel 4 programme Foxes Live
came out this week on British television.

668.text:
Channel 4 filmed urban foxes, showed how cuddly
they are and tracked them with GPS collars,

673.text:
up and down the country. This of course makes
locating and possibly shooting Patch Grace

678.text:
Chico, Ringtail, Basil Deisel or Rathbone
very easy. One of the shooting forums has

685.text:
already suggested this, then putting the collars
on eBay. We rang Channel 4's production company

691.text:
saying this would certainly spice things up
a bit - they asked us not to shoot the foxes

695.text:
until after they have collected the GPS data,
which will be after 13th May 2012.

701.text:
They are giving guns to kids in Gloucestershire
again this weekend. The Schools Challenge

707.text:
and Festival of Shooting at Bredon School
are both on this weekend at Bredon School

711.text:
near Tewkesbury. There are plenty of shooting
sports for you to enjoy and a prize pot worth

716.text:
£6,000 in the open clay competition on Monday.
Visit www.theschoolschallenge.co.uk

724.text:
Rugby player, Scott Armstrong, has shot a
gold medal buck, provisionally measured at

729.text:
70 points. That's a few more points than he
has scored for Northampton Saints in the last

734.text:
couple of seasons, where he plays winger.
He was out with new stalking guide Muntjacstalker.

743.text:
Now for a piece of road rage in South Africa.
This contestant for Team Jeep South Africa

748.text:
was riding hard when he was hit by a red hartebeest.
Let's just watch that again. Ouch. He ends

754.text: up with a very stiff neck.

758.text:
And finally we've been sent some exclusive
footage of cock fighting - first made illegal

763.text:
in England and Wales in 1835, this fierce
battle was filmed at a barn in Surrey. Thankfully

769.text:
neither of the cock sparrows was killed and
were later seen courting and making nests

773.text:
within minutes of the fight being broken up.
No one was arrested.

779.text:
You are now up to date with Fieldsports Britain
News. Stalking the stories. Fishing for facts.

790.text:
Thank you David. Still sticking out like a
sore thumb.

793.text:
Now we all know that there is no camouflage
like realtree camouflage and this week Teamwild

798.text:
TV is wrapping their trucks in the very best
patterns that realtree has to offer. Click

803.text:
on the angry buck which has appeared in the
sky up there and you can watch that film.

807.text:
We are staying in Scotland and finding out
why it is such a popular destination for shooters

815.text:
Scotland is where the world wants to be in
April and May. The combination of great roebuck

820.text:
stalking and superb pigeon mean shooters will
travel thousands of miles, put up with the

826.text:
often amusing food and brave the uncertain
weather for a chance at these two prized quarry.

833.text:
Alan what does it take to put together a three-day
trip like this for a party, of how many, 6

842.text:
Six yes, start by doing a lot of reconnaissance
work before they arrive, look where the deer

850.text:
are. Obviously these guys are here for 3 days,
6 stalks. So we spent like 3 days looking

857.text:
And the pigeon shooting here, do they have
this kind of thing in France, they must do?

861.text:
Very little, very little, they only have a
two week window for the migration of pigeons.

870.text: Then after that they have nothing.

872.text:
Really, so they are basically stuck, they
have got to come here.

874.text: They have got to come here yes.

875.text: Or Hungary, which is 25 times more expensive.

878.text: So you are in a good place here.

880.text:
We are in a good place and we try to provide
very good shooting for them.

885.text:
We are in Perthshire with a party of French

You may have seen Decathlon shops outside

Decathlon is, it is a very well kept secret

And there are several of them here in the

There are 12 or 13 of them over here in the

They are big, they are anywhere from 3,000

And you sell hunting gear which is kind of

It is unusual for an English sports shop,

shop and it is very normal particularly for

977.text:
And you don’t have Decathlon written on

That is absolutely right. Each of Decathlon’s

identity and their own name. Solognac actually

992.text:
biggest hunting region in France and the Bordeaux

998.text:
in ac so ‘ac’ which now has the highest

1004.text:
We are here in Scotland. In terms of Europe
what does Scotland mean. What is it to European

1010.text:
Scotland means deer stalking, it means hunting,
it means everything we know about Scotland,

1016.text:
everything we think about Scotland the Europeans
share that view.

1020.text:
So the French consider Scotland a really good

1024.text:
The French consider Scotland a fantastic place

1027.text:
was only one name in Europe to come and test

1033.text:
The weather might be foul but the pigeon shooting
is excellent and tests the guns to their limits.

1039.text:
Birds that normally go past at around 55 miles
an hour are breaking the national speed limit

1049.text:
We are also here to stalk roedeer. All of
us get either highseats or accompaniment.

1054.text:
I go out with a local stalker, Sean. He shows

1061.text:
morning. But either they are does or in the

a cull buck in the right place and I start

1073.text:
buck is just over the brow. It hasn't seen

and it's off . So no roebuck for me but the
French have a good time.

1088.text:
We are in Perthshire with sporting agent Cervus

For the last targets of the evening he is

the problem is that they are head on, they

make sure they get that shot bang. I would

And it doesn't stop there. Tim is really going

the quarry and possibly the erratic technique

What I will be doing is flashing the spotlight

the fox, sometimes I will be putting on the

rest. Tom picked a duff post to lean on. And,

Tim gives them 10 seconds to shoot. There

1616.text:
are firebirds on these targets. Roy the spoilsport
nabs both his and Tom's. Naughty.

1624.text:
There is 3 shots here which tells me one person
has been shooting the wrong target, Lupton?

1630.text:
The shots are still good even if greedy Lupton
has taken both foxes. So what does Tom think

1638.text:
First time I have shot at a target in the
dark, so the whole thing was a new experience

1643.text:
So how did you find the light because the
light was moving a wee bit.

1646.text:
That didn’t bother me too much. I was just
trying to get my cross hairs in the middle

1651.text:
of the 2 cats eyes looking at me, fox eyes
in this case. The light wasn’t too distracting

1660.text:
I think a lot of people think foxing is easy,
but there is an awful lot to consider.

1665.text:
I thought it was a lot harder. I always thought
the idea of lamping easy, you see the fox

1670.text:
under the lamp, but it is completely different,
you don’t, you see the 2 little spots looking

1676.text:
The next two targets are the one in the track
and its neighbour. Range is an issue here

1680.text: and the shooting sticks also cause problems.

1684.text:
Last but one are the targets we first looked
at in daylight. Tom has a real problem here

1689.text:
but Roy is in his comfort zone and the little
tinker even shoots one of Tim's reflectors.

1693.text: Have you shot one of my eyes?

1698.text:
Last up are the head on foxes. Tom is again
struggling - it's getting late and we're all

1702.text:
tired - Tim takes over and sees the last Firebird
go bang.

1708.text: So what do the chaps think of the evening?

1710.text:
So what is your advice to anyone who wants
to go fox shooting for the first time?

1716.text:
At night, get a warm jacket, be calm and have
confidence I think.

1724.text: Is it how you thought it would be?

1726.text:
Better actually, I must admit. First of all
I thought you would see the big fox coming

1730.text:
and it would nice and easy a bit like your
deer stalking, but it is completely different.

1736.text:
You don’t see the animal, you do have to
have confidence in where you are shooting

1743.text: and you will hit the target.

1745.text:
Tim has been keeping a score of how the guys
have performed - Roy has shot well but has

1750.text:
been a bit fruity with not keeping to his
own target.

1754.text:
We have got Roy here who tends to shoot anything
in front of him. He shot 2 eyes out of my

1760.text:
foxes, he shot somebody else’s target, so
Roy is very, very greedy. So we have got the

1764.text:
youngster as well who has shot very, very
well. So tonight I think the winner is going

1769.text:
to be the youngster Tom, so well done Tom.
You shot very well.

1781.text:
Films about fox shooting is one of our specialities.
There is a fox now. If you click on it you

1788.text: Next, it is our weekly Youtube round-up.

1790.text:
Icelandic viewer nesvargur1 has sent us his
handheld minkhunting video from the land of

1803.text:
Vikings, volcanoes and now vermin. It's in
a funny foreign language but it has top action

1808.text:
shots of dogs hunting Ivana Trump's favourite
pest.

1812.text:
Talking of vermin, viewers have complained
that we were unwarrantably rude about HuntersVermin's

1818.text:
video for Airgun TV in last week's episode.
We love HuntersVermin and, to prove it, here

1824.text:
is his excellent latest, Air Rifle Hunting,
Farm Yard Vermin Control.

1829.text:
The people behind Sporting Rifle magazine,
Blaze Publishing, have brought out their own

1834.text:
video magazine show, The Shooting Show. It
has items about going shooting, it has an

1839.text:
annoying presenter, and a slightly weird newsreader...
Now why didn't we think of that?

1844.text:
OnlineFishingTV has brought out latest Fly
Fishing News film. It's a video bulletin of

1849.text:
the latest goings on in the world of fly fishing,
in the UK and overseas.

1854.text:
LionsgateFilms has put up some clips and this
behind-the-scenes look at the filming of the

1859.text: new flyfishing epic Salmon Fishing in

1873.text:
the Yemen. Far too much romance, not enough
fishing.

1878.text:
YorkshireRoeStalking has a dramatic new film
called 'Misfire nearly costs us a buck' - clue

1883.text:
is in the title but you have to feel for the
shooter when both you and the deer hear the

1887.text:
rifle go click. Luckily, he reloads quietly
enough not to spook the animal.

1893.text:
Gregloginway has produced a short series called
'How to boil out deer head'. This is from

1899.text:
part three, which is about bleaching a non
medal trophy head. It's not going to win an

1904.text:
award for cinematography but handy if you
want to know how. Oops, there we go being

1910.text:
And finally, viewer Philip140, a Brit who
lives in Canada, has sent us a film about

1916.text:
how to make your own shoot-and-see targets
with nothing but some white laminated paper

1924.text:
You can click on any of these films to watch
them. If you have a YouTube film you would

1928.text:
like us to pop in to the weekly top eight,
send it in via YouTube, or email me the link

1937.text:
Well we are back next week and if you are
watching this on Youtube don’t hesitate

1941.text:
to hit the subscribe button which is somewhere
on the edge of the screen, they keep moving

1945.text:
it around, or we are of course a Youtube show.
You can go to www.youtube.com/shows/fieldsportsbritain

1954.text:
and subscribe there. Or go to our website
www.fieldsportschannel.tv scroll down to the

1959.text:
bottom, there is a box there you pop your
email address in and we spam you with news

1964.text:
of our programme every week, similarly on
Facebook and on Twitter, same place.

1970.text:
This has been Fieldsports Britain, out here,
on the hill, in the sun, suffering, trying

1976.text: not to look smug for you.
